audio_caption: The clip begins with an intense and dramatic orchestral piece, evoking a heroic mood. The main voice, a male speaker with an academic tone, starts by introducing himself as "Professor Jim Cathy". He describes the content as "the lecture video for Astronomy, Chapter One" and states that videos will be created for each chapter in every module.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker's voice, transitioning directly into a PowerPoint presentation discussing Chapter 1, with the presenter stating "Let's go ahead and jump into the PowerPoint," then "Chapter 1." The speaker mentions "a tour around the universe," then describes colliding galaxies. He details, "when galaxies collide, they...kind of merge into a morph of each other", as well as mentions two spiral galaxies that are "kind of like the Milky Way," and states that the Hubble space telescope captured the picture.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing a "red planet Mars" mosaic, focusing on Mariner Valley and its canyon-like features. He states the valley is so big it makes the Grand Canyon look tiny and would go across the United States six times deeper. The speaker continues, describing a stellar corpse and how a massive star explodes and dies, referencing the Crab Nebula observed in 1054 by the Chinese, whom he credits as the first observational astronomers. He mentions that the bright stuff seen is gas and heavy elements like calcium and iron, which form what we see in our bodies, bones, and blood. The audio ends with the same speaker starting a new sentence.

An individual is speaking in an informative tone about space and astronomy, describing what he deems "the most beautiful thing in the entire night sky", the Orion Nebula. He shares that this is a star-birthing region, stating "stars are born in the forms of human lives". He mentions his past research on the stars within it, before transitioning to the Hubble Space Telescope. The speaker notes that it will be replaced soon and explains that it was named after Edwin P. Hubble, an American astronomer from Marshfield, Missouri. He mentions the local recognition in the speaker's community, including a one-third scale replica in the town square.

The audio begins with a male speaker describing Earth, referring to it as the "pale blue dot" and explaining that the image is from a geostationary satellite, which is used for communication, TV broadcasts, and weather satellites. He speaks in an informative and somewhat educational tone. He then describes what it would look like to scale the earth and the moon together, mentioning the distance and size differences.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker describing the "entire solar system family," including the four small planets, the four gas giants, and dwarf planets like Pluto and Ceres, with a calm and informative tone. He mentions that Ceres used to be an asteroid and Pluto used to be the ninth planet, and adds that Pluto is now a dwarf planet. At the end, we hear a quiet, ambient sound of whooshing, adding a sense of the vastness of space.

The audio clip features a male speaker describing a spiral galaxy, noting that it's "probably a barred spiral galaxy," with blue and white areas indicating gas and stars forming, and dark lanes of dust. The speaker explains that gas and dust make up the ingredients for new stars. Following his description, there is a distinct clicking sound.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing an image, "a long time-lapse image of the Milky Way Galaxy," and contrasting the visibility of the galaxy based on location, mentioning cities with light pollution versus the desert of Arizona and Kitt Peak National Observatory. He expresses awe at the sight, emphasizing how different it is from a place like the Las Vegas strip. The clip ends with a brief static sound.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing a "globular star cluster," mentioning that they have hundreds of millions of stars and are spherical in shape. He notes that they are old stars surrounding the Milky Way galaxy.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing looking at galaxies using millimeter light and radiation. He mentions cold hydrogen with 21-centimeter radiation, using radio telescopes to view a group of radio telescopes in Chile looking at nearby minor galaxies. He shifts focus to the nearest galaxy, Andromeda, calling it a "great Andromeda galaxy," twice the size of the Milky Way. He notes that the Milky Way and Andromeda are coming together, and someday they will collide. He pivots to discussing the Fornax cluster galaxies and speaks of "look back time," looking back in the history of the universe to see how galaxies used to be, adding everything in the picture is a galaxy.

The audio clip features a single male speaker with an informative tone. He explains how different events would occur on a calendar year if the entire timeframe of the universe was shrunk down. He states that the Big Bang would be on January 1st, the Milky Way would form in May, our solar system would start to form around September, and the first complex life forms would come in November. He also specifies that dinosaurs came on Christmas day and went extinct on the 30th. Then finally, in the last few hours of the last day, humans appeared.

The clip begins with a male speaker expressing gratitude for joining a video lecture. A different male speaker is then heard promoting a YouTube channel, inviting viewers to watch more videos and subscribe. Finally, the clip ends with a polite expression of thanks from the speaker.
